Name: Stela with Pointed Acroteria
Description: A gable, in the center of a raised circular ornament, is situated over an oblong stela. On two sides, there are pointed acroteria, or small pedestals. A piece is missing from one of these pedestals. Beneath the gable there is an inscription of three lines: "IOCOTTHNET EKBEOCKPY IC." Below this inscription there is a rectangle with a circular ornament in which is a cross inside a circular notch. Above two sides of the rectangle there is a raised circular ornament similar to that in the center of the gable. Beneath the sides of the rectangle there are palm leaves with a cross in the center. The lower part of the panel is devoid of any ornament. The museum has over 200 funeral inscriptions, some are in greek ans others in copt.This panel was found in the monasteries west of Alexandria. Similar panels have been found in various parts of Upper and Lower Egypt, especially in Aswan, Akhmim, and Ashmunein. Some are made of marble, while others are made of sandstone from Aswan, or of limestone, some of which is from the quarries of El Maks in Alexandria. Some of these funerary panels are triangular, others are oblong with a gable at the top.
